theory.tonic-desc: The home chord that provides stability and resolution. Songs often start and end on this chord.
theory.subdominant-desc: Creates a sense of departure from home, often leading to the dominant. Provides harmonic contrast.
theory.dominant-desc: Creates tension that wants to resolve back to the tonic. Essential for establishing key centers.
theory.variable-desc: Can serve different harmonic functions depending on the musical context and key.
theory.default-desc: Serves various harmonic functions in different musical contexts.

chord-explanations.major: A major chord built on {root}, containing a major third (4 semitones) and perfect fifth (7 semitones). Creates a bright, stable, and happy sound that forms the foundation of Western harmony.
chord-explanations.minor: A minor chord built on {root}, containing a minor third (3 semitones) and perfect fifth (7 semitones). The flattened third gives it a darker, more melancholic character compared to major chords.
chord-explanations.dominant-7th: A major triad with an added minor seventh (10 semitones from root). This creates harmonic tension that naturally wants to resolve, making it essential in blues, jazz, and classical harmony.
chord-explanations.major-7th: A major triad with an added major seventh (11 semitones from root). Creates a dreamy, sophisticated sound popular in jazz and contemporary music. Less tense than dominant 7th chords.
chord-explanations.minor-7th: A minor triad with an added minor seventh. Commonly used in jazz, R&B, and funk, it's less sad than a plain minor chord and adds harmonic richness without strong tension.
chord-explanations.suspended: Replaces the third with either a second (sus2) or fourth (sus4), creating an open, unresolved sound that neither major nor minor. Often resolves back to the major or minor version.
chord-explanations.diminished: Built entirely of minor thirds (3 semitones each), creating maximum harmonic tension. Often used as passing chords or to create dramatic, unstable moments in music.
chord-explanations.augmented: Contains a major third and augmented fifth (8 semitones), creating a mysterious, floating quality. The augmented fifth creates harmonic ambiguity and is popular in impressionist music.
chord-explanations.eleventh: An extended chord that includes the 11th degree (4th) in addition to the basic triad. Creates rich, complex harmonies popular in jazz and contemporary music.
chord-explanations.add: A chord with an added note that extends the basic triad without creating a full seventh chord. Common additions include 9th, 11th, and 13th intervals.
chord-explanations.default: A {quality} chord with unique harmonic properties that adds color and character to musical progressions.

tips.b-major: B major is challenging for beginners - try the easier version higher up the neck first
tips.minor-comfort: Minor chords often feel more comfortable when you arch your fingers well to avoid muting adjacent strings
tips.beginner-friendly: This is a great chord for beginners - focus on clean finger placement and avoid touching other strings
tips.advanced-available: Advanced variations available - master the basic form first before attempting more complex fingerings
tips.practice-slowly: Practice chord changes slowly at first, focusing on accuracy over speed
tips.clean-notes: Make sure each string rings clearly by pressing firmly just behind the frets
